message: that's how we do it at github, cmheisel

I work on a large team (~30 devs). We're currently using a git workflow where we have a feature branch, we build that feature to a feature environment (assuming all tests pass). We do a bit of manual testing and then fix any bugs and merge the feature branch into master (and do a prod release from there).

But then I saw this about Prezi's workflow: http://reinout.vanrees.org/weblog/2011/06/07/continuous-integration.html and I'm wondering if switching to master + feature flag workflow would help us out, esp. with rebase/merge hell?
@peritus The book (http://continuousdelivery.com/) is also highly recommended!
Here's an interview with Martin Fowler and Jez Humble (author of "Continous Delivery") explaining feature branch hell and what to do: http://www.infoq.com/interviews/jez-humble-martin-fowler-cd
@chacon -- One large team all editing on master I take it and not the way we're currently working?

We had this discussion in my office recently, while everyone liked the idea, it really seemed to fall down at the DB level. Perhaps we were a little unimaginative, but feature flagging DB schema changes, something we seem to end up doing a lot (it's an inherited, never going to be refactored mess of a thing), didn't really seem practical.
@cmheisel no, feature branches and pull requests.  We only touch master to bring in things that are safe to be deployed... and almost always deploy them immediately.
@kennethreitz Looks like merge hell to me.
@peritus it's git, there is no merge hell.
